yes, users only have rights over her home (security). Use sudo
example 'sudo mkdir /media/iso_images'
so you have. you can use sudo. other users can not use sudo
that would be a security risk... if you have to use sudo you will be more carefull on what you do and will not make as many mistakes as you will otherwise do (trust me ;))

is a symlink to /proc/self/mounts <---> lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 11 2010-05-13 12:24 /proc/mounts -> self/mounts
but that does not matter much; does it ?

you can not edit that file.... is informative just like /proc/cpuinfo or /proc/meminfo
it shows what it is mounted and where. the file to modify is /etc/fstab
